name: Computing & OS Security
description: Sector template for operating system and endpoint security patents including malware protection, sandboxing, kernel security, and endpoint detection and response (EDR).
contextDescription: Computing and OS security patents protect endpoints and operating systems from malware, unauthorized access, and exploitation. Technologies include antivirus/antimalware, application sandboxing, kernel hardening, memory protection, EDR/XDR, host-based intrusion prevention, VMI security, and confidential computing.
scoringGuidance: Kernel-level and hypervisor security patents generally have higher value due to privileged access.
Patents addressing fileless malware, living-off-the-land attacks, and evasion techniques score higher.
Cross-platform applicability (Windows, Linux, macOS, mobile) increases market_relevance.
EDR/XDR patents with behavioral analysis outperform signature-only solutions.
Hypervisor/VMI security patents leveraging privilege separation are high value for cloud security.
Memory protection and deception techniques addressing advanced threats are emerging high-value areas.
Agentless security approaches for cloud and container environments have growing market relevance.

questions.question: At what OS layer does this patent operate? Score 1-3 for user-space application, 4-6 for system services/drivers, 7-10 for kernel/hypervisor level.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Identify the operating system layer: user-space, kernel, hypervisor.

questions.question: How effective is the malware detection approach? Score 1-3 for signature matching only, 4-6 for behavioral analysis, 7-10 for advanced detection (fileless, rootkits, bootkits, APT).
questions.reasoningPrompt: Describe malware detection capabilities and evasion resistance.

questions.question: Does this patent implement process/application isolation? Score 1-3 if none, 4-6 for application sandboxing, 7-10 for hardware-backed isolation (TEE, SGX, VM-based).
questions.reasoningPrompt: Describe isolation technology: sandboxing, containers, VMs, TEEs.

questions.question: What endpoint types does this patent cover? Score 1-3 for single OS/platform, 4-6 for desktop/server coverage, 7-10 for comprehensive coverage (desktop, server, mobile, IoT).
questions.reasoningPrompt: List supported platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS, Android, iOS, IoT.

questions.question: Does this patent include endpoint detection and response functionality? Score 1-3 if protection only, 4-6 for detection and forensics, 7-10 for full EDR/XDR with automated response.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Assess EDR capabilities: telemetry, investigation, automated response.

questions.question: Does this patent leverage hypervisor or VMI (Virtual Machine Introspection) capabilities? Score 1-3 if not applicable, 4-6 for VM-aware security, 7-10 for hypervisor-level privilege separation or VMI-based protection.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Assess hypervisor/VMI relevance for cloud and virtualized security.

questions.question: Does this patent address advanced memory-based attacks? Score 1-3 if not applicable, 4-6 for standard memory protection, 7-10 for advanced techniques (memory deception, CFI, shadow stacks, anti-ROP).
questions.reasoningPrompt: Assess memory protection depth: basic, hardening, or advanced deception.

questions.question: Does this patent support agentless security or cloud-native deployment? Score 1-3 if agent-required only, 4-6 for hybrid agent/agentless, 7-10 for fully agentless or cloud-native security.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Assess agentless capability and cloud-native deployment applicability.
